name: Onyx Sleet TTPs
description: TTPs identified in Onyx Sleet's cyber operations

techniques.comment: Onyx Sleet has been known to exploit existing vulnerabilities for client execution. The report provides an example whereby the threat actor exploited the TeamCity CVE-2023-42793 vulnerability, which allowed for remote code execution and administrative control of the affected server.
Onyx Sleet has used exploits as a primarily means of gaining initial access to target environments, focusing notably on N-day vulnerabilities.
Onyx Sleet executes arbitrary commands via command shell using malware such as the 'LightHand' backdoor which can also perform file manipulations.
Onyx Sleet uses remote access trojans (RATs) and employs the flexible command and control strategy of using leased virtual private servers (VPS) and compromised cloud infrastructure.
The threat actor may have gained access by leveraging improperly managed legitimate credentials, but this was not explicitly mentioned in the text.
Onyx Sleet uses heavy custom encryption and obfuscation to avoid detection. Commercial packers like Themida and VMProtect are used to obfuscate their malware.
Onyx Sleet has been known to sign payloads with an invalid certificate masquerading as legitimate software to evade detection.
Onyx Sleet's tactics involve launching as much of its code in memory as possible to avoid common detection techniques which could be considered indicative of a form of process injection.
Onyx Sleet has historically leveraged spear-phishing as a means of compromise, though this approach is mentioned to now be more limited in its recent campaigns.
Onyx Sleet uses its own encryption algorithm. Appears to have been done to evade detection or avoid decryption.
